- [NA]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed?
- "‎We identified no trials that satisfied the criteria for this review."
- [NA]

A11. Was the conflict of interest included?
- "‎Authors' declarations of interest"
- [Yes], the conflict of interest was included.

Summary: The systematic review did not find any trials that met the inclusion criteria, therefore the methodological quality of the review cannot be fully assessed. However, the review did provide an a priori design, performed a comprehensive literature search, and appropriately used the lack of high-quality evidence in formulating conclusions.

161. Wang 2013: Systematic review and meta-analysis of studies comparing the perimeatal-based flap and tubularized incised-plate techniques for primary hypospadias repair

AMSTAR
A1 A2 A3 A4 A5 A6 A7 A8 A9 A10 A11
Human Consensus 0 1 0 0 0 1 1 1 1 1 0
LLM 2nd run 1 1 1 0 1 1 1 1 NA 1 NA


LLM response

8 quote(s) from publication full text (mean similarity 100%)

A1. "‎The PubMed, Embase and Cochrane databases were searched using the terms: hypospadias, Snodgrass, TIP*, tubularized incised plate, tubularized incised-plate, Mathieu*, perimeatal-based flap, perimeatal flap, meatal-based flap and meatal based flap." [Yes]
- The study clearly states the search strategy used to identify relevant studies.

A2. "‎The eligibility determination, quality assessment and data extraction for each study were conducted independently by two of the authors (FRW and YHX) and conflicts were resolved by a third author (HJZ)." [Yes]
- The study mentions that two authors independently conducted the eligibility determination, quality assessment, and data extraction, and conflicts were resolved by a third author.

A3. "‎The PubMed search used a search strategy including both medical subject heading terms and free-text words. The following terms were used: hypospadias, Snodgrass, TIP*, tubularized incised plate, tubularized incised-plate, Mathieu*, perimeatal-based flap, perimeatal flap, meatal-based flap and meatal based flap." [Yes]
- The study provides details of the search strategy used, including the databases searched and the specific terms used.

A4. No information provided. [No]

A5. "‎From the 94 citations initially identified, 12 studies [2, 3, 10–19] including 690 cases (338 cases for PBF and 352 cases for TIP) fulfilled the predefined inclusion criteria and were included in the final analysis." [Yes]
- The study states that 12 studies were included in the final analysis and provides the references for these studies.

A6. "‎We extracted data from each study using a predefined data extraction form. The variables assessed included first author, publication year and type, level of evidence, patient age and number, length of follow-up, patient characteristics, surgical techniques and details (coverage of the neo-urethra, suture material and fashion, urinary diversion), and postoperative outcomes (fistula, meatal stenosis, wound dehiscence and cosmesis)." [Yes]
- The study describes the data extraction process and provides details of the variables assessed.

A7. "‎Among the included studies, there were seven RCTs [10–12, 15, 16, 18, 19] and five cohort studies [2, 3, 13, 14, 17], eleven studies [2, 3, 10–15, 17–19] published as full-text articles and one [16] as abstract, and nine studies [2, 3, 10, 12, 14, 15, 17–19] published in English and three [11, 13, 16] in other languages." [Yes]
- The study provides information on the study design and publication details of the included studies.

A8. "‎There were no significant differences of complication rates between the two techniques, and the TIP technique was usually of better cosmesis." [Yes]
- The study considers the scientific quality of the included studies in formulating conclusions.

A9. No information provided. [NA]

A10. "‎Possible publication bias was analyzed by generating funnel plots of the studies used for all of the evaluated comparisons of outcomes. Only one study [17] lied outside the 95 % CI and the funnel plots of fistula, meatal stenosis and wound dehiscence showed no obvious asymmetry, suggesting little evidence of publication bias." [Yes]
- The study assesses the likelihood of publication bias by analyzing funnel plots.

A11. No information provided. [NA]

Overall, the methodological quality of the systematic review is adequate based on the AMSTAR criteria. The review provides details of the search strategy, includes a list of included studies, extracts data from each study, and considers the scientific quality of the included studies in formulating conclusions. However, it does not provide information on the assessment of publication bias or conflict of interest.

162. Wayne 2015: What is the ideal surgical approach for intra-abdominal testes? a systematic review

AMSTAR
A1 A2 A3 A4 A5 A6 A7 A8 A9 A10 A11
Human Consensus 1 1 1 0 0 1 1 1 NA NA 0
LLM 2nd run 1 1 1 NA 0 0 1 0 NA NA 1


LLM response

26 quote(s) from publication full text (mean similarity 100%)

A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided?
- "‎We conducted a systematic review of literature focusing on the surgical treatment of IAT, including quality assessment of each study." 
- "‎We used a Dephi-like method [16] to determine the issues of greatest concern to pediatric surgeons regarding the surgical management of cryptorchid testes."
- "‎We sent an online survey to 34 experts with proficiency in this area, identified primarily on the basis of a literature search."
- "‎We developed a questionnaire listing all the issues raised by the experts in the first round."
- "‎We conducted electronic searches of the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL), MEDLINE, EMBASE, and CINAHL from inception to September 2014."
- "‎We used the following search terms: “Cryptorchidism” AND “Intra-abdominal” OR “Abdomen/abdominal cavity/inguinal canal/groin.”"
- "‎We included all studies that examined diagnostic and surgical correction techniques for IAT, even if this was not the primary focus of the study."
- "‎Our outcomes of interest were success of orchiopexy (testis viable and located in the scrotum), testicular atrophy, and intra-operative and post-operative complications."
- "‎Article screening took place in two stages—title and abstract, and full-text screening—both of which were conducted independently by two reviewers, followed by a consensus process."
- "‎We used AMSTAR [18] to assess the quality of all relevant systematic reviews (SRs)."
- "‎Had we identified any randomized controlled trials (RCTs), we would have used the Cochrane ‘Risk of bias’ tool [19] to assess their quality."
- "‎We used MINORS [20] to assess the quality of all relevant non-randomized studies (comparative or non-comparative)."
- "‎Two reviewers independently assessed each included study and compared the scores for each item on the applicable quality assessment tool to reach a consensus."

Reasoning: The authors clearly describe the methods used to conduct the systematic review, including the search strategy, study selection process, and quality assessment tools used. They also mention using a Delphi-like method to determine the research question and issues of concern to pediatric surgeons. Therefore, an 'a priori' design was provided.
Answer: [Yes]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction?
- "‎Article screening took place in two stages—title and abstract, and full-text screening—both of which were conducted independently by two reviewers, followed by a consensus process."
- "‎Two reviewers independently assessed each included study and compared the scores for each item on the applicable quality assessment tool to reach a consensus."

Reasoning: The study selection and data extraction processes were conducted independently by two reviewers, followed by a consensus process. Therefore, there was duplicate study selection and data extraction.
Answer: [Yes]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
- "‎We conducted electronic searches of the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL), MEDLINE, EMBASE, and CINAHL from inception to September 2014."
- "‎We used the following search terms: “Cryptorchidism” AND “Intra-abdominal” OR “Abdomen/abdominal cavity/inguinal canal/groin.”"
- "‎We also hand-searched the reference sections of included articles for additional relevant studies."

Reasoning: The authors conducted a comprehensive literature search by searching multiple databases and hand-searching reference lists. They also provide details of the search terms used. Therefore, a comprehensive literature search was performed.
Answer: [Yes]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
- No relevant quotes.

Reasoning: The text does not mention whether the status of publication was used as an inclusion criterion. Therefore, it is not clear if the authors searched for grey literature or unpublished literature.
Answer: [NA]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided?
- "‎We performed full-text screening for these articles, excluding 17 that did not meet our criteria [7, 10, 22–36]. The remaining 31 studies comprised two SRs and 29 non-randomized studies; we quality assessed and summarized these studies (Table 1)."

Reasoning: The authors mention that they performed full-text screening and excluded 17 studies that did not meet their criteria. They also provide a summary table of the included studies. However, they do not explicitly state whether a list of excluded studies was provided. Therefore, it is unclear if a list of excluded studies was provided.
Answer: [No]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided?

Reasoning: The authors mention that they quality assessed and summarized the included studies, but they do not provide specific details about the characteristics of the included studies. Therefore, it is unclear if the characteristics of the included studies were provided.
Answer: [No]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented?
- "‎We used AMSTAR [18] to assess the quality of all relevant systematic reviews (SRs)."
- "‎Had we identified any randomized controlled trials (RCTs), we would have used the Cochrane ‘Risk of bias’ tool [19] to assess their quality."
- "‎We used MINORS [20] to assess the quality of all relevant non-randomized studies (comparative or non-comparative)."
- "‎Two reviewers independently assessed each included study and compared the scores for each item on the applicable quality assessment tool to reach a consensus."

Reasoning: The authors clearly state that they used quality assessment tools (AMSTAR, Cochrane 'Risk of bias' tool, and MINORS) to assess the scientific quality of the included studies. They also mention that two reviewers independently assessed each included study and reached a consensus. Therefore, the scientific quality of the included studies was assessed and documented.
Answer: [Yes]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions?
- "‎The results of our systematic review should, therefore, be interpreted with caution."

Reasoning: The authors mention that the results of the systematic review should be interpreted with caution due to the overall lack of good-quality evidence. However, they do not explicitly state whether the scientific quality of the included studies was used in formulating conclusions. Therefore, it is unclear if the scientific quality of the included studies was used appropriately in formulating conclusions.
Answer: [No]

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate?
- No relevant quotes.

Reasoning: The text does not mention any methods used to combine the findings of studies. Since the authors state that meta-analysis was not possible due to heterogeneity of the data, it is unclear if any other methods were used to combine the findings. Therefore, it is not clear if the methods used to combine the findings of studies were appropriate.
Answer: [NA]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed?
- No relevant quotes.

Reasoning: The text does not mention any assessment of publication bias. Since the authors state that there were no RCTs and only two SRs of relatively low quality, it is unclear if publication bias was assessed. Therefore, it is not clear if the likelihood of publication bias was assessed.
Answer: [NA]

A11. Was the conflict of interest included?
- "‎The authors declare that they have no conflict of interest."

Reasoning: The authors explicitly state that they have no conflict of interest. Therefore, the conflict of interest was included.
Answer: [Yes]

- It is unclear whether the methods used to combine the findings of studies were appropriate. [NA]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed?
- No information is provided about the likelihood of publication bias being assessed.
- It is unclear whether the likelihood of publication bias was assessed. [NA]

- It is unclear whether the conflict of interest was included. [NA]

166. Wright 2013: Effect of Preoperative Hormonal Stimulation on Postoperative Complication Rates After Proximal Hypospadias Repair: A Systematic Review

Human Consensus 0 1 1 1 0 1 1 1 1 1 0
LLM 2nd run 1 1 1 0 0 1 1 0 1 1 NA


LLM response

7 quote(s) from publication full text (mean similarity 100%)

A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided?
- "‎We conducted a systematic review and meta-analysis to summarize the effect of preoperative hormonal stimulation on complication rates following proximal hypospadias repair."
- The study clearly states the research question and objective of the review.
- [Yes]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction?
- "‎Title, abstract and full text screening was carried out by 2 independent authors, and discrepancies were resolved by consensus."
- There were two independent authors involved in study selection and data extraction.
- [Yes]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
- "‎We conducted a comprehensive search of MEDLINE®, Embase, CINAHL, SciELO, CENTRAL, Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews and reference lists of prominent studies from 1990 to 2010."
- The search included multiple databases and reference lists.
- [Yes]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
- No information is provided about the inclusion or exclusion of grey literature.
- [No]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided?
- No information is provided about the inclusion or exclusion of studies.
- [No]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided?
- "‎All patients underwent 1 of 5 surgical techniques, which included OIF (323 patients, 52%), TIP (134, 22%), Koyanagi urethroplasty (95, 15%), 2-stage repair (44, 7%) and buccal mucosa graft repair (26, 4%)."
- The characteristics of the included studies are provided in terms of surgical techniques used.
- [Yes]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented?
- "‎Critical appraisal of the included studies was carried out by 2 independent reviewers using a quality assessment instrument adopted from Elyas et al,14 modified to fit the objectives of this study."
- The scientific quality of the included studies was assessed using a quality assessment instrument.
- [Yes]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions?
- No information is provided about how the scientific quality of the included studies was used in formulating conclusions.
- [No]

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate?
- "‎Four studies containing homogeneous patient and intervention characteristics were pooled for a meta-analysis."
- The findings of studies were combined using a meta-analysis.
- [Yes]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed?
- "‎Asymmetry in the funnel plot indicates that publication bias may be present, as there is a relative paucity of studies describing high complication rates."
- The likelihood of publication bias was assessed using a funnel plot.
- [Yes]

A11. Was the conflict of interest included?
- No information is provided about the conflict of interest.
- [NA]

Overall, the methodological quality of the systematic review is moderate. The review clearly states the research question and objective, uses duplicate study selection and data extraction, performs a comprehensive literature search, provides characteristics of the included studies, assesses the scientific quality of the included studies, uses appropriate methods to combine the findings of studies, and assesses the likelihood of publication bias. However, the review does not provide a list of included and excluded studies, does not use the scientific quality of the included studies appropriately in formulating conclusions, and does not include information about conflict of interest.

- "‎Eligibility criteria included all available studies comparing LH with OH (without diagnostic hernioscopy) for the repair of PIH and with quantitative data on outcome parameters."
- "‎Each included article was appraised by 3 reviewers (YCL, ZHY, and TQS), who assessed the methodological quality of the selected studies independently."
- [Yes], an 'a priori' design was provided as the research question and inclusion criteria were established before the conduct of the review.

- "‎Three reviewers (YCL, ZHY, and TQS) independently assessed selected studies, extracted, and tabulated data from each article with a predefined data extraction form."
- [Yes], there was duplicate study selection and data extraction.

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
- "‎All published studies until July 30, 2010, were searched with the terms laparoscopy, laparoscopic herniorrhaphy, pediatric inguinal hernia, and open herniorrhaphy from Medline (using PubMed as the search engine), Embase, Ovid, Web of Science, and Cochrane databases, without lower date limit."
- [Yes], a comprehensive literature search was performed.

- [No] information provided.

- [Yes], a list of studies (included and excluded) was provided.

- "‎A summary of the studies' method, intervention characteristics, and measured outcomes was provided in Table 1, Table 2, and Table 3."
- [Yes], the characteristics of the included studies were provided.

- [No] information provided.

- [Yes], the methods used to combine the findings of studies were appropriate.

- [No] information provided.

A11. Was the conflict of interest included?
- [No] information provided.

AMSTAR

LLM response

Minor score formatting issues fixed during extraction: ‘missing-squared-brackets-in-unnumbered-list’

7 quote(s) from publication full text (mean similarity 100%)

A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided?
- "‎A registered systematic review (PROSPERO: CRD42015016745) of comparative studies was performed, querying multiple databases without language or date restrictions." 
- [Yes], an 'a priori' design was provided.

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction?
- "‎Multiple reviewers independently assessed study eligibility and literature quality."
- [Yes], there was duplicate study selection and data extraction.

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
- "‎The protocol of this review was prospectively published in the PROSPERO registry (CRD42015016745). Papers with pertinent titles were systematically identified by searching the following sources: AMED, PubMed, MEDLINE, Cochrane, EMBASE, Africa-wide information, Biosys, Global Health, LLAOS, and Web of Science in November 2014 with no date or language restrictions."
- [Yes], a comprehensive literature search was performed.

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
- [No] information provided.

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided?
- [No] information provided.

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided?
- "‎The characteristics of the included studies are highlighted in Table 1."
- [Yes], the characteristics of the included studies were provided.

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented?
- "‎The quality of included studies was evaluated by the Newcastle-Ottawa Scale (NOS) for case–control studies shown in Table 2."
- [Yes], the scientific quality of the included studies was assessed and documented.

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions?
- [No] information provided.

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate?
- "‎Meta-analysis was performed for primary and secondary outcomes using RevMan 5.2 (Copenhagen)."
- [Yes], the methods used to combine the findings of studies were appropriate.

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed?
- "‎A Funnel plot of the log odds ratio against the standard error for these nine studies demonstrated relative asymmetry, suggesting potential publication bias."
- [Yes], the likelihood of publication bias was assessed.

A11. Was the conflict of interest included?
- [No] information provided.

Summary: The systematic review adequately addressed most of the AMSTAR criteria, but there is missing information regarding the inclusion of grey literature, the provision of a list of included and excluded studies, the appropriate use of scientific quality in formulating conclusions, and the inclusion of conflict of interest.

170. Zani 2015: Is single incision pediatric endoscopic surgery more painful than standard laparoscopy in children? Personal experience and review of the literature.

AMSTAR
A1 A2 A3 A4 A5 A6 A7 A8 A9 A10 A11
Human Consensus 0 0 0 0 0 1 0 0 NA NA 0
LLM 2nd run 1 0 1 NA 1 1 1 1 NA NA NA


LLM response

11 quote(s) from publication full text (mean similarity 100%)

A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided?
- "‎After Internal Review Board approval, a prospective study was performed on all patients undergoing SIPES between March 2010 and March 2011 at our institution." 
- "‎To determine whether SIPES was associated with different levels of postoperative pain than SL, a systematic review of current literature was performed."
- "‎Only comparative articles that were published between January 2008 and November 2012 and that analysed postoperative pain following SIPES or SL in children were included."
- [Yes] The study design was clearly described as a prospective study and a systematic review.

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction?
- No information provided.
- [No] No mention of duplicate study selection and data extraction.

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
- "‎Scientific databases (PubMed, Medline, OVID, ERIC, and Cochrane Collaboration) were searched using the keywords “single port surgery” and “child”."
- "‎Of the 102 retrieved articles that met the search criteria, eight reported a comparison of postoperative pain levels following SIPES and SL procedures in children."
- [Yes] A comprehensive literature search was performed using multiple databases and keywords.

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
- No information provided.
- [NA] No mention of the status of publication as an inclusion criterion.

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided?
- "‎Eight studies that we analysed are then further supported by a series of non-comparative articles."
- [Yes] A list of included studies was provided.

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided?
- "‎The 10 SIPES procedures were compared with 10 similar SL procedures, performed in children possibly of similar age, weight and gender."
- [Yes] The characteristics of the included studies were provided.

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented?
- "‎The primary endpoint of our study was to investigate whether there were differences in postoperative analgesia requirement following SIPES or SL."
- [Yes] The scientific quality of the included studies was assessed by investigating the postoperative analgesia requirement.

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions?
- "‎In our patient series, SIPES was not associated with increased postoperative pain compared to SL."
- [Yes] The scientific quality of the included studies was used appropriately in formulating conclusions.

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate?
- "‎We also confirmed that SIPES was followed by satisfactory wound healing and was judged excellent by patients and parents."
- [NA] Not applicable as there was no mention of combining the findings of studies.

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed?
- "‎The eight studies that we analysed are then further supported by a series of non-comparative articles."
- [NA] Not applicable as there was no mention of assessing publication bias.

A11. Was the conflict of interest included?
- No information provided.
- [NA] No mention of conflict of interest.

171. Zhao 2015: Single-incision versus conventional laparoscopic appendicectomy in children: a systematic review and meta-analysis

LLM response

Minor score formatting issues fixed during extraction: ‘missing-squared-brackets-for-na’, ‘missing-squared-brackets-in-unnumbered-list’

8 quote(s) from publication full text (mean similarity 100%)

A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided?
- "‎The aim of this systematic review and meta-analysis was to compare clinical outcomes between single-incision laparoscopic appendicectomy and conventional laparoscopic appendicectomy in children." (Introduction)
- "‎To evaluate the safety and efficacy of SILA in the treatment of pediatric appendicitis, the authors collected 12 published studies to perform a meta-analysis." (Discussion)
- [Yes], the research question and inclusion criteria were established before the conduct of the review.

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction?
- "‎Two authors independently extracted data from the list of the included studies, and a third reviewer was required for a final decision in the case of any discrepancies." (Methods)
- [Yes], there were two independent data extractors and a consensus procedure for disagreements.

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
- "‎An electronic search was performed using EMBASE, PubMed, MEDLINE from 2000 to 2014." (Methods)
- [Yes], at least two electronic sources were searched.

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
- No information provided.
- [NA]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided?
- "‎The initial search strategy identified 213 citations and 26 of them were retrieved for full text review. Twelve trials met total inclusion criteria." (Results)
- [Yes], a list of included studies was provided.

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided?
- "‎Table 1 outlines basic demographic data from each included study, including study style, male:female sex ratio and BMI (kg/m2) or weight (kg) in each group." (Results)
- [Yes], the characteristics of the included studies were provided.

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented?
- No information provided.
- [NA]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions?
- "‎Our study suggests that SILA is a feasible and safe surgical procedure alternative to CLA for pediatric patients with appendicitis." (Discussion)
- [Yes], the scientific quality of the included studies was used in formulating conclusions.

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate?
- "‎Meta-analysis demonstrated no statistically significant in mean operating time for SILA compared with CLA." (Results)
- [Yes], appropriate methods were used to combine the findings of studies.

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed?
- No information provided.
- [NA]

A11. Was the conflict of interest included?
- No information provided.
- [NA]

172. Zhu 2016: Minimally invasive surgery for congenital diaphragmatic hernia: a meta-analysis

AMSTAR
A1 A2 A3 A4 A5 A6 A7 A8 A9 A10 A11

LLM 2nd run 1 1 1 NA 1 1 0 0 NA NA 1


LLM response

7 quote(s) from publication full text (mean similarity 100%)

A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided?
- "‎A literature search was performed using the PubMed database, Embase, and the Cochrane central register of controlled trials using a defined set of criteria."
- "‎Studies that met all the following criteria were included in the meta-analysis: (1) the trial was a randomized or non-randomized clinical trial; (2) the study was designed to compare surgical outcomes of neonates with CDH between MIS intervention and open procedures; and (3) data on incidence of mortality, recurrence, patch use, and surgical complication rate were fully or partially reported."
- Yes, an 'a priori' design was provided.

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction?
- "‎Two authors (Zhu and Wu) independently performed an electronic database search to identify studies that met the eligibility criteria."
- Yes, there was duplicate study selection.

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
- "‎We performed a literature search of the PubMed database (National Library of Medicine, Bethesda, MD, USA) that covered the period from 1966 to December 2013. The search conducted for Embase and the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials was restricted to English-language literature."
- Yes, a comprehensive literature search was performed.

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
- No information provided.

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided?
- "‎Our (Zhu and Wu) preliminary search revealed 70 relevant studies, and 61 of them were eventually excluded because they were merely narrative studies or case reports or did not evaluate the surgical outcomes that were the focus of this review."
- Yes, a list of excluded studies was provided.

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided?
- "‎All nine clinical trials [3–11] compared thoracoscopic or laparoscopic (only four laparoscopic cases) repair of CHD with open techniques."
- Yes, the characteristics of the included studies were provided.

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented?
- No information provided.

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions?
- No information provided.

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate?
- No information provided.

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed?
- No information provided.

A11. Was the conflict of interest included?
- "‎YZ declares no conflict of interest. YW declares no conflict of interest. QP declares no conflict of interest. LM declares no conflict of interest. HL declares no conflict of interest. LL declares no conflict of interest."
- Yes, the conflict of interest was included.

Based on the information provided in the full text, the assessment of the methodological quality of the systematic review using the AMSTAR tool is as follows:
A1. [Yes]

A4. [NA]
A5. [Yes]

A7. [No]

A9. [NA]

Quote accuracy

  • 888 quotes for 112 / 112 (100%) publications, median 8 (IQR 5-9, range 2-26)
  • 851 / 888 (95.8%) perfect quotes from the publication full text
  • 4 / 888 (0.5%) perfect quotes from the LLM prompt briefing - were instructions quoted (ok) or examples (unwanted beahviour)?
  • 33 / 888 (3.7%) quotes with deviations from source, where the accuracy was measured by a “normalized Levenshtein similarity” with custom weights, ranging from 0-100%
    • 16 minor deviations (95% ≤ similarity < 100%); mean: 98.5%
    • 4 moderate deviations (75% ≤ similarity < 95%); mean: 88.3%
    • 13 major deviations (similarity < 75%); mean: 55.2%

Formatting accuracy

  • 65 / 112 (58%) usable responses with correctly formatted scores
  • 47 / 112 (42%) usable responses with minor fixable score formatting issues
    • 43 with ‘missing-squared-brackets-in-unnumbered-list’
    • 33 with ‘missing-squared-brackets-for-na’
    • 3 with ‘wrong-response-partial-unclear-etc-without-squared-brackets’
    • 2 with ‘wrong-response-partial-unclear-etc’

  • 112 / 112 (100%) publications yielded usable responses in the first try
  • 0 / 112 (0%) publications yielded usable responses after a median of NA retries (IQR NA-NA, range Inf–Inf), thus being ultimately successful
  • 0 / 112 (0%) publications yielded no usable responses and were thus ultimately unsuccessful.

LLM prompt

  • Model: gpt-3.5-turbo-16k-0613
  • Temperature: 0
  • Briefing derived from: Cullis 2017 Supporting information: S1 Dataset

System prompt

You are an expert in systematic reviews and are tasked to assess the methodological quality of a systematic review with the AMSTAR tool based on the full text of its publication. AMSTAR consists of the following items:

---
# AMSTAR
A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided? The research question and inclusion criteria should be established before the conduct of the review. Note: Need to refer to a protocol, ethics approval, or pre-determined/a priori published research objectives to score a “yes.”
A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction? There should be at least two independent data extractors and a consensus procedure for disagreements should be in place. Note: 2 people do study selection, 2 people do data extraction, consensus process or one person checks the other’s work.
A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed? At least two electronic sources should be searched. The report must include years and databases used (e.g., Central, EMBASE, and MEDLINE). Key words and/or MESH terms must be stated and where feasible the search strategy should be provided. All searches should be supplemented by consulting current contents, reviews, textbooks, specialized registers, or experts in the particular field of study, and by reviewing the references in the studies found. Note: If at least 2 sources + one supplementary strategy used, select “yes” (Cochrane register/Central counts as 2 sources; a grey literature search counts as supplementary).
A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion? The authors should state that they searched for reports regardless of their publication type. The authors should state whether or not they excluded any reports (from the systematic review), based on their publication status, language etc. Note: If review indicates that there was a search for “grey literature” or “unpublished literature,” indicate “yes.” SIGLE database, dissertations, conference proceedings, and trial registries are all considered grey for this purpose. If searching a source that contains both grey and non-grey, must specify that they were searching for grey/unpublished lit.
A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided? A list of included and excluded studies should be provided. Note: Acceptable if the excluded studies are referenced. If there is an electronic link to the list but the link is dead, select “no.”
A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided? In an aggregated form such as a table, data from the original studies should be provided on the participants, interventions and outcomes. The ranges of characteristics in all the studies analyzed e.g., age, race, sex, relevant socioeconomic data, disease status, duration, severity, or other diseases should be reported. Note: Acceptable if not in table format as long as they are described as above. Paul "Follow-up poorly reported in general"
A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented? 'A priori' methods of assessment should be provided (e.g., for effectiveness studies if the author(s) chose to include only randomized, double-blind, placebo controlled studies, or allocation concealment as inclusion criteria); for other types of studies alternative items will be relevant. Note: Can include use of a quality scoring tool or checklist, e.g., Jadad scale, risk of bias, sensitivity analysis, etc., or a description of quality items, with some kind of result for EACH study (“low” or “high” is fine, as long as it is clear which studies scored “low” and which scored “high”; a summary score/range for all studies is not acceptable).
A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions? The results of the methodological rigor and scientific quality should be considered in the analysis and the conclusions of the review, and explicitly stated in formulating recommendations. Note: Might say something such as “the results should be interpreted with caution due to poor quality of included studies.” Cannot score “yes” for this question if scored “no” for question A7.
A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate? For the pooled results, a test should be done to ensure the studies were combinable, to assess their homogeneity (i.e., Chi-squared test for homogeneity, I2 ). If heterogeneity exists a random effects model should be used and/or the clinical appropriateness of combining should be taken into consideration (i.e., is it sensible to combine?). Note: Indicate “yes” if they mention or describe heterogeneity, i.e., if they explain that they cannot pool because of heterogeneity/variability between interventions.
A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed? An assessment of publication bias should include a combination of graphical aids (e.g., funnel plot, other available tests) and/or statistical tests (e.g., Egger regression test, Hedges-Olken). Note: If no test values or funnel plot included, score “no”. Score “yes” if mentions that publication bias could not be assessed because there were fewer than 10 included studies.
A11. Was the conflict of interest included? Potential sources of support should be clearly acknowledged in both the systematic review and the included studies. Note: To get a “yes,” must indicate source of funding or support for the systematic review AND for each of the included studies.
---

User prompt

This is the full text to be assessed:
---
%FULLTEXT%
---

For each of the 11 AMSTAR questions (A1 to A11) perform the following steps:
1. Extract 1-3 relevant quotes from the full text.
2. Explain your reasoning in 1 sentence.
3. Respond to the question with either "[Yes]" if adequate, "[No]" if inadequate, or "[NA]" if not applicable or not relevant to the text (for example, combining data in quantitative synthesis (A9) or assessing publication bias (A11) in the context of a systematic review without a meta-analysis).

Before stopping, make sure you've processed all 11 AMSTAR questions. Do not provide a final summary paragraph in the end.
